__data__.text: Born in Spain in 1919, Picardo studied architecture after his initial plans to join the navy and study law were disrupted. He began his architecture studies during the Spanish Civil War and worked in the studio of Luis Moya Blanco to avoid evacuation. Due to the war, there was a shortage of architects in Spain, and Picardo's artistic skills were noticed by many architects. He painted murals, illustrated architectural magazines, and focused on historical architecture during his studies. After qualifying in 1951, Picardo collaborated on building preservation and restoration projects with architect Fernando Chueca Goitia. He was one of the signatories of the "Manifiesto de la Alhambra" in 1952, which sought to create a distinctively Spanish form of modern architecture inspired by the Alhambra in Granada. This interest in historical architecture shaped Picardo's work throughout his career.

Picardo, an architect who studied in Spain, was inspired by the unchanging elements of Spanish architecture, particularly as seen in the Alhambra in Granada. This interest was sparked during his time working with Chueca Goitia and was further developed when he co-signed the "Manifiesto de la Alhambra" in 1952, which called for a distinctly Spanish form of modern architecture inspired by historical designs. This influence can be seen throughout Picardo's career, particularly in his work on the Paradores.

In the 1950s, Picardo pursued personal architectural ambitions, entering competitions and publishing uncommissioned building plans. He collaborated with his brother on an apartment building near Madrid's Plaza de Las Ventas and built houses in Andalucía and Madrid. He also received commissions for decorative mural paintings and illustrations in architectural textbooks.

Picardo's skills as a draughtsman were highly regarded, with his quick sketches and detailed drawings recognized for their quality. In 1959, he received a unique commission to design a pack of playing cards for the Spanish fashion brand Loewe.

Picardo's skills as a muralist and architectural draftsman were highly regarded, with his works published in a popular textbook on Spanish architecture and described as "magnificent." In 1959, he was commissioned to design a pack of playing cards for Loewe, featuring historical figures. Around the same time, he also created a set of wooden chess pieces. In the early 1960s, Picardo began working with Paradores de Turismo, a state-run hotel chain, where he dedicated much of his professional life to restoring and converting historic buildings into luxury hotels while maintaining their original appearance and incorporating them into his modern designs. His work for Paradores was highly regarded and influenced other architects in Spain and Portugal.

Over the course of nearly twenty years, Picardo undertook eleven major restoration projects for Paradores de Turismo, converting historical buildings into luxury hotels while preserving their original style and incorporating them into his modern designs. His work, which included the use of ancient construction techniques and the creation of furniture and decorative elements, greatly influenced other architects in Spain and Portugal.

One of his first projects was the Parador de Guadalupe, where he transformed two ruined buildings, the Hospital de San Juan Bautista and the Colegio de Infantes, into a hotel. He preserved the original Mudéjar style of the buildings, using lime, clay, and wood in their reconstruction. The main hospitality section of the Parador was located in the Colegio de Infantes, while the Hospital de San Juan Bautista was remodeled for kitchens, service areas, and staff residences. Picardo also added a new wing to the Parador in 1981, increasing the number of guest rooms to 41.

At the same time as the Guadalupe project, Picardo was commissioned to design and build a Parador at the Castillo de Santa Catalina in Jaén, Andalucía.

Picardo constructed the Parador de Jaén at the Castillo de Santa Catalina in Jaén, Andalucía, while working on the Parador de Guadalupe. The castle, built in the 13th century, had been abandoned and was in disrepair. Picardo decided to build the Parador on the site of the old barracks and stables, rather than in the castle itself, to take advantage of the views and avoid altering the castle's original structure. The first phase of the Parador, completed in 1965, included a dining room, lounge, service areas, and 7 double guest rooms, with additional rooms and facilities added in later phases. Picardo designed the building to resemble the castle, using modern materials hidden beneath traditional stone, brick, timber, and iron. He also added 24 guest rooms in a westward extension in 1973, bringing the total to 43 and elevating the building to the title of Parador. The interior was designed to continue the medieval ambiance, with furniture, wall-hangings, and other details created by Picardo.

In 1965, Picardo added 24 guest rooms to the initial 19 built in the first phase of the Parador de Jaén, raising the total to 43. The extension, constructed due to land layout constraints and height limitations, resulted in long corridors and distances between rooms and public areas. The building was elevated to the title of Parador upon completion of this extension in 1978.

Picardo designed the interior, creating furniture, wall-hangings, shutters, carpets, light fittings, door furniture, and floor and wall tile patterns to maintain the medieval atmosphere. He also incorporated coats of arms from demolished buildings and featured hand-painted written ceramic tiles by Juan Manuel Arroyo for decoration and credit.

In an architectural magazine article in 1967, Picardo expressed his satisfaction with the building's mood and aura, acknowledging his "maestros" (masters) who had not seen the finished project. The style established at Jaén and Guadalupe was continued in later works, such as the Parador de Arcos de la Frontera in Cádiz, Andalucía.

At Arcos de la Frontera, Picardo preserved façades while demolishing other structures, incorporating seven reused columns into the new building's design. He addressed a 15 cm crack in the cliff by constructing a separate patio on an independent structure. The Parador's design mirrored a typical Andalucían residence, featuring exposed pine wood joists, vaulted plasterwork, and terracotta floors. Picardo designed much of the interior furniture, fittings, lighting, and decoration, using ceramic tiles for both decoration and explanatory texts. Initially, only 9 of the planned 18 guest rooms were built, with some facing the plaza and others overlooking the cliff-edge view.

In 1965, Picardo added 24 guest rooms to the initial 19 at the Parador de Jaén, resulting in a medieval-style building with long corridors and distant rooms. He also designed the interior, incorporating Andalucían architectural features and ceramic tiles for decoration. A similar style was used in the Parador de Arcos de la Frontera in Cádiz, Andalucía, where Picardo preserved façades, reused columns, and built an independent structure to address a crack in the cliff. The building was designed to resemble a typical Andalucían residence, with exposed pine wood joists, vaulted plasterwork, and terracotta floors. Picardo also designed much of the interior furniture, fittings, lighting, and decoration, using ceramic tiles for both decoration and explanatory texts.

In 1965, Picardo was commissioned to restore the Casa de la Inquisición in Pedraza, Castilla y León, turning it into a hostería without guest rooms. He followed the rustic style of the region's inns, building a spacious lounge, bar, and 90-seat dining-room. Picardo also designed his own furniture and other fittings, lighting and decoration. He later proposed expanding the property by purchasing neighboring buildings to provide extensive views of the Sierra de Guadarrama, but the project was not realized.

In 1966, Picardo began converting the Palacio de los Comendadores at Alcañiz in Aragon into a Parador. He transformed the immense south wing into a medieval-style building with limited space and 12 guest rooms. The public areas included the conversion of two large and long ground floor interiors with pointed barrel-vaulted ceilings on each side of the building's entrance.

In 1966, Picardo was tasked with converting part of the Palacio del Comendador de Alcúescar in Cáceres into a Hostería. He chose to work on a jumble of old buildings, mostly stables and coach houses, attached to the main palace. He kept a square structure with substantial stone walls and four brick, groin vaults, converting its lower ground floor into the bar and main entrance. He added three more floors, reusing architectural elements from the demolished buildings.

Meanwhile, at the Alcañiz Parador, Picardo faced limited space, allowing for only 12 guest rooms. He converted the ground floor's large interiors into the reception area, bar, and cafetería. The first floor held the main dining room with a large fireplace and coffered ceiling. Guest rooms were on the second floor, with raised areas for window views. Picardo designed the interior in a medieval style for the ground floor and a more palatial decor for the upper floors. He used the emblem of the Order of Calatrava as a decorative motif and incorporated ceramic murals.

Picardo had proposed expanding the Alcañiz Parador as early as 1972, and his 1975 designs were realized in 1998, doubling the number of guest rooms to 38.

In 1966, Picardo was assigned to convert part of the Palacio del Comendador de Alcúescar into a Hostería. He decided to work on a collection of old structures, primarily stables and coach houses, connected to the main palace. He kept a square building with robust stone walls and four brick, groin vaults, transforming its lower ground floor into the bar and main entrance. He added three more floors, reusing architectural elements from the demolished buildings. Additionally, he created a new one-story building, imitating local structures and designed the interior in a medieval style. The Hostería opened in 1971, and Picardo also undertook the re-roofing of the palace and an extension to the dining room. The Hostería was later closed in 1984, and the rest of the palace was converted into a Parador with 27 guest rooms.

Picardo was also commissioned to inspect three ancient sites near Sevilla, and he chose the Alcázar del Rey Don Pedro in Carmona. He began preparatory work in 1968 and built the Parador in the southeast of the castle area, a corner known as the Plaza de Armas. The castle, probably of Muslim origin, was restored in the 14th century and used by the Catholic Monarchs of Spain. It was abandoned after being severely damaged in earthquakes. Picardo chose this site as he was enthusiastic about its historical significance and provided preliminary sketch designs, which the Ministry accepted.

In 1968, Picardo began preparing to build a Parador in Carmona, at the highest point of the town, overlooking the plains and utilizing the Plaza de Armas in the southeast of the vast, abandoned castle area. The castle, of probable Muslim origin and restored in the 14th century, had been severely damaged by earthquakes and left with seven remaining towers and ruined connecting walls. Despite discovering a deep crack and subsidence in the intended location for the Parador's southern wall, Picardo proceeded with the construction, stabilizing the ground with cement and a reinforced concrete slab.

The Parador, completed in 1971, featured a typical Hispanic-Arabic layout with two central patios, resembling the original fortress. The building, primarily on the southern and eastern walls, had four floors on the steeply sloping lower sections and two floors on the parade ground side. Initially planned with 23 double and 10 single guest rooms, the building's capacity was expanded to 102 rooms due to a delay in construction. The structure was built in Picardo's signature style, with a concrete frame, ashlar and brickwork cladding, and a clay pantile roof. The interior boasted a palatial Mudéjar style with limestone columns, ceramic tiling, and subtle changes in design throughout the rooms.

The Parador in Carmona, completed in 1971, was built with a concrete frame, ashlar and brickwork cladding, and a clay pantile roof in Picardo's signature style. The interior featured a palatial Mudéjar style with limestone columns, ceramic tiling, and subtle changes in design. Despite issues with a large crack and subsidence, the building's capacity was expanded to 102 rooms. In 1976, King Juan Carlos I and Queen Sofía inaugurated the building, but later that year, a large crack was detected, and an expansion joint was constructed. The building continued to experience movement, and the Service Geológico de Obras Públicas recommended underpinning the south wall's foundations. However, due to new government policy, Picardo could not be involved in the building's structural problems after 1978. Minor improvements and modernizations were carried out in 1982 and 1983, and an expansion was completed in 1987. The building is currently at risk in the event of a sharp rise in the water table or another earthquake.

Regarding the Castillo de Sigüenza, Picardo considered it the best proposition for a new Parador in the Province of Guadalajara despite being comprehensively ruined. The castle, which had Iberian, Roman, Visigothic, and Moorish origins, was enlarged and modified between the 14th and 18th centuries. However, it declined and deteriorated, suffering damage during the French invasion, the Carlist Wars, and the Spanish Civil War. Picardo analyzed the condition of the building in October 1969 and found it to be in a pitiful state.

The Castillo de Sigüenza, a palace-fortress with a rich history dating back to Iberian, Roman, Visigothic, and Moorish times, stands prominently above Sigüenza's town and cathedral. After decades of decline and damage from various wars, it was in ruins by 1969. Picardo, commissioned to assess its condition, found it covered in plaster and later additions, with numerous collapses and openings. He proposed a total reconstruction of the castle as a medieval fortress, removing later additions and restoring its military appearance. This involved raising outer walls, rebuilding destroyed sections, removing large windows, and crenellating surrounding walls and towers. The interior was rebuilt with modern materials hidden behind a historical veneer, and the central courtyard was cleared of post-medieval elements. Picardo's design prioritized a unified medieval style, emphasizing the castle's warrior character. However, the building remains at risk due to its history of instability and potential rises in the water table or earthquakes.

The Castillo de Sigüenza, which was in ruins by 1969, underwent a reconstruction led by Picardo to restore its medieval appearance. He removed later additions, raised outer walls, rebuilt destroyed sections, and added crenellations. The interior was built with modern materials and included a historical veneer, and the central courtyard was cleared of post-medieval elements. Picardo's design resulted in 38 guest rooms and one suite on the first floor, and 42 rooms and one suite on the second floor, with a total capacity for 162 guests. He also added a small monastic courtyard, a banqueting hall, and service areas. Picardo's signature style included the use of timber, stone, brick, and iron, and he took care to preserve the castle's original chapel. The Parador opened to the public in 1976 and was later remodeled in 1990, but it has maintained its original character. Despite the castle's history of instability and potential risks, Picardo's reconstruction successfully transformed it into a medieval fortress.

Picardo, the architect who led the reconstruction of the Castillo de Sigüenza, completed the first stage of the project in 1976 and opened the Parador to the public in 1978. He also worked on several other old buildings to convert them into Paradores, including the castle in Puebla de Alcocer and the remains of the castle in Monzón, but these projects did not materialize. Picardo was known for his historical and architectural research, which he used to plan the rebuilding projects without archaeological research. His style was followed in the 1990 remodeling of the Sigüenza Parador, which maintained its original character. Picardo's legacy includes several Paradores that were built based on his designs and plans, as well as buildings that were surveyed but not converted into Paradores.

Picardo, the architect known for his work on Paradores, improved the castle-turned-Parador in Ciudad Rodrigo in 1975. His rebuilding projects, often based on personal historical and architectural research instead of archaeological studies, have been controversial. Critics argue that his approach resulted in "false history" and "medieval scenery for tourist accommodation." However, Picardo, who saw architecture as art, believed that the end justified the means, using modern techniques disguised with traditional materials. Despite contemporary criticism, his Paradores, such as those in Jaén, Carmona, and Sigüenza, remain popular. Besides Paradores, Picardo also restored various historical buildings, including Catedral de Cádiz, Real Monasterio de Santa María de Guadalupe, Catedral de Santa María de Sigüenza, Antiguo Palacio del Marqués de Montana, Palacio de Gamazo, Castillo de San Felipe, and Archivo Histórico Provincial de Salamanca.

Picardo, renowned for his Paradores, was invited to design the Fundación Juan March headquarters in Madrid in 1970, after Juan March appreciated his work in Jaén. Inspired by classical Greek and New York architecture, Picardo's modern, elegant design won the competition in 1971. The building, completed in 1975, features a cube shape, continuous horizontal banding, and alternating ribbon windows and marble cladding. Inside, there are assembly halls, auditoria, exhibition spaces, libraries, offices, and underground parking. Picardo integrated artworks and designed a notable garden for the project. The building, inaugurated in 1975, received praise for its design and proportions, with Picardo considering it his best work. Besides Paradores, Picardo restored various historical buildings, including Catedral de Cádiz, Real Monasterio de Santa María de Guadalupe, Catedral de Santa María de Sigüenza, Antiguo Palacio del Marqués de Montana, Palacio de Gamazo, Castillo de San Felipe, and Archivo Histórico Provincial de Salamanca.

Picardo's building for the Fundación Juan March featured artworks by Chillida, Serrano, and Vaquero Turcios, as well as notable sculptures designed by Picardo himself, such as the large bronze double doors. The adjacent garden, also designed by Picardo, was intended to be a significant part of the project. The building, inaugurated in 1975, received praise for its design and proportions. Later, Picardo was commissioned to design the Salón de Equitación for the Real Escuela Andaluza del Arte Equestre in Jerez de la Frontera, completed in 1980. He used a neo-Renaissance style, referencing Andalucía's colors and architecture. In 1981, Picasso's Guernica was brought to Spain and Picardo, along with José García María de Paredes, designed a secure display for the painting in the Museo Nacional del Prado's Salón de Luca Giordano. They used armored glass and a steel polyhedron case to protect the painting from potential harm while avoiding reflections.

After completing the Fundación Juan March building and the Salón de Equitación, Picardo and José García María de Paredes faced a challenge designing a display for Picasso's Guernica in 1981 due to size limitations of available armored glass. They opted for a steel polyhedron case and mounted the painting on a distant wall to avoid reflection issues. The display was well-received by some, but others had reservations. In 1992, the painting was moved to the Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofía. Picardo, elected to the Real Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando in 1997, gifted the academy his oil painting Guardia civil en el puerto de Alazores in 2000 and was awarded the Premio Antonio Camuñas de Arquitectura in 2001. His contributions to architecture have been recognized for their thoughtful integration of historical heritage.

In 1953, Picardo painted an informal portrait of himself at the age of 34, which was later donated to the academy by his sons in 2023. He was posthumously awarded the prestigious Premio Antonio Camuñas de Arquitectura in 2001 for his architectural contributions, which highlighted the value of Spain's historical heritage. Picardo, who married Trinidad de Ribera Talavera and had five children, was known for his energy, wit, and imagination. He passed away in Madrid on July 27, 2010.
